## CES-D vs AOSI

Psychologists, researchers, and social scientists are frequently tasked with the challenge of comparing questionnaires like the Centre for Epidemiological Studies-Depression (CES-D) and Autism Observation Scale for Infants (AOSI), also known as CES-D vs AOSI. The CES-D discusses symptoms associated with depression, while AOSI is an interactive assessment for evaluating behaviours that may indicate the presence of autism. Whilst the CES-D vs AOSI seems a daunting task for comparison, with Harmony, this complex process is simplified and made significantly more efficient. Harmony, a cutting-edge software solution, provides the technology needed to harmonise questionnaires, even when they are as different as the CES-D and AOSI. Built on robust AI and natural language processing models, Harmony can provide a percentage match between each item in these two completely different scales. The CES-D vs AOSI exercise becomes less tedious and less subjective, with greatly improved speed and an assurance of greater accuracy. The application of Harmony to CES-D vs AOSI, or any other pair of disparate scales, lies in its ability to allow comparisons both within and across studies. This is instrumental in enabling researchers to verify the consistency of results across varied studies, or gauge differences in response to changing societal conditions. Advantageously, Harmony has the ability to handle questionnaires in different languages, further expanding the scope for international research studies. Simplify your CES-D vs AOSI comparison by using Harmony and experience a seamless questionnaire harmonisation process.

## Compare the items in CES-D English and AOSI

* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import CES-D and AOSI into Harmony and harmonise them</a> - find similarities between the two instruments using our AI platform
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just CES-D into Harmony</a> - compare CES-D English with other instruments
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just AOSI into Harmony</a> - compare AOSI with other instruments
